variants.question: Which of the following is/are a direct consequence(s) of applying a force to an object?

options.option_text: Change in shape
Change in mass
Change in velocity
Change in material

variants.question: A constant force is applied to an object. Which of the following changes could occur to the object? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: The object's shape changes.
The object's mass changes.
The object's velocity changes.
The object's material changes.

variants.question: Which of the following scenarios best illustrates the effect of a force on an object's velocity?

options.option_text: A stationary ball starts rolling when pushed.
A clay ball flattens when pressed.
The mass of a metal block changes when heated.
A wooden block changes color when painted.

variants.question: A block is being pulled across a rough surface. Which of the following forces act on the block?

options.option_text: Applied Force
Tension
Friction
Normal Reaction Force

variants.question: A block is pulled horizontally across a rough surface at a constant speed. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the magnitudes of the forces acting on the block?

options.option_text: The applied force is equal to the frictional force.
The applied force is greater than the frictional force.
The applied force is less than the frictional force.
The normal reaction force is greater than the weight of the block.

variants.question: A block of mass $!$m$!$ is pulled across a rough horizontal surface with a constant applied force $!$F$!$. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the surface is $!$\mu_k$!$. Which of the following expressions represents the magnitude of the frictional force acting on the block?
When the net force acting on an object is zero, the object is said to be in:

options.option_text: Motion
Equilibrium
Centripetal acceleration
Inertia

variants.question: Which of the following statements is correct about an object when the net force acting on it is zero?

options.option_text: The object must be at rest.
The object must be moving at a constant velocity.
The object must be accelerating.
The object's motion cannot be determined.

variants.question: Select all the scenarios in which an object can be considered to be in equilibrium.

options.option_text: An object moving with constant velocity in a straight line.
An object at rest.
An object accelerating uniformly.
An object moving in a circle at constant speed.

variants.question: What does the spring constant ($!$k$!$) measure?

options.option_text: The limit of proportionality of the spring.
The stiffness of the spring.
The force applied to the spring.
The extension of the spring.

variants.question: Which of the following is true regarding the spring constant ($!$k$!$)?

options.option_text: A higher value of $!$k$!$ indicates a stiffer spring.
A lower value of $!$k$!$ indicates a stiffer spring.
$!$k$!$ is measured in meters.
$!$k$!$ represents the force applied to a spring at its breaking point.

variants.question: Select all the statements that correctly describe the spring constant ($!$k$!$):

options.option_text: It is a measure of the stiffness of the spring.
It relates the force applied to a spring and its extension or compression.
It is independent of the material the spring is made of.
It is measured in Newtons (N).

variants.question: Which formula represents Hooke's Law?
Select all the equations that are dimensionally consistent with Hooke's Law ($!$F = kx$!$), where F is force, k is the spring constant, and x is displacement.
A spring obeys Hooke's Law. If the displacement is doubled, what happens to the force exerted by the spring?

options.option_text: The force is doubled.
The force is halved.
The force remains the same.
The force is quadrupled.

variants.question: Which of the following properties are exhibited by force?

options.option_text: Magnitude
Direction
Colour
Taste

variants.question: A force of $!$10 N$!$ is applied on an object in the North direction. Which of the following correctly describes the force?

options.option_text: Magnitude only
Direction only
Both magnitude and direction
Neither magnitude nor direction

variants.question: Which of the following are vector quantities?

options.option_text: Force
Mass
Speed
Weight

variants.question: What is the property of matter that resists changes in motion?

options.option_text: Force
Inertia
Moment
Acceleration

variants.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes inertia?

options.option_text: The force that causes acceleration.
The property of matter that resists changes in velocity.
The rate of change of velocity.
The force of gravity on an object.

variants.question: Which of the following examples demonstrate the concept of inertia? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: A stationary object remaining at rest unless acted upon by an external force.
An object in motion continuing to move with the same velocity unless acted upon by an external force.
An object accelerating due to an applied force.
The gravitational force between two objects.

variants.question: According to Newton's Second Law, what is the relationship between force, mass, and acceleration?

options.option_text: Force is directly proportional to mass only.
Force is directly proportional to acceleration only.
Force is proportional to both mass and acceleration.
Force is inversely proportional to both mass and acceleration.

variants.question: According to Newton's Second Law ($!$F = ma$!$), which of the following statements correctly describes the relationship between force ($!$F$!$), mass ($!$m$!$), and acceleration ($!$a$!$)? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: If the mass is kept constant, the force is directly proportional to the acceleration.
If the acceleration is kept constant, the force is inversely proportional to the mass.
If the force is kept constant, the acceleration is inversely proportional to the mass.
If the mass is doubled and the acceleration is halved, the force remains constant.

variants.question: If the mass of an object is doubled while the net force acting on it remains constant, what happens to the acceleration of the object according to Newton's Second Law?

options.option_text: The acceleration is doubled.
The acceleration is halved.
The acceleration remains the same.
The acceleration is quadrupled.

variants.question: What formula represents Newton's Second Law?
A 2 kg block accelerates at 5 m/s$!$^2$!$ on a frictionless surface. According to Newton's Second Law, what is the net force acting on the block?
Which of the following statements correctly describe Newton's Second Law? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: Force is directly proportional to acceleration when mass is constant.
Force is inversely proportional to mass when acceleration is constant.
The net force acting on an object is equal to the product of its mass and acceleration.
An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by a net force.

variants.question: One Newton is the force required to accelerate 1 kg of mass by:

options.option_text: 1 m/s

variants.question: Which of the following statements about the Newton ($!$N$!$) unit of force is correct?

options.option_text: One Newton is the force required to accelerate 1 kg of mass by 1 m/s.
One Newton is the force required to accelerate 1 kg of mass by 1 m/s$!$^2$!$.
One Newton is the force required to accelerate 1 kg of mass by 9.8 m/s$!$^2$!$.
One Newton is the force required to accelerate 1 kg of mass by 0 m/s$!$^2$!$.

variants.question: Select all the statements that correctly describe the relationship between force, mass, and acceleration, where force is measured in Newtons ($!$N$!$).

options.option_text: A force of 1 N is required to accelerate a 1 kg mass at 1 m/s$!$^2$!$.
A force of 2 N is required to accelerate a 2 kg mass at 1 m/s.
A force of 9.8 N is required to accelerate a 1 kg mass at 9.8 m/s$!$^2$!$.
A force of 1 N is required to keep a 1 kg mass moving at a constant velocity of 1 m/s.

variants.question: Which of the following best describes the direction of acceleration in relation to the net force?

options.option_text: Perpendicular
Opposite
Same direction
At an angle of 45 degrees

variants.question: According to Newton's Second Law of Motion, if the net force acting on an object doubles, what happens to the object's acceleration?

options.option_text: Acceleration doubles.
Acceleration halves.
Acceleration remains the same.
Acceleration becomes four times the original value.

variants.question: Select all the statements that correctly describe the relationship between net force and acceleration.

options.option_text: Net force and acceleration are directly proportional.
Acceleration is in the same direction as the net force.
Net force and acceleration are inversely proportional.
Acceleration is opposite to the direction of the net force.

variants.question: What is the main effect of friction?

options.option_text: Converts potential energy to kinetic energy
Converts kinetic energy into thermal energy
Increases kinetic energy
Reduces thermal energy

variants.question: Which of the following scenarios primarily demonstrates the effect of friction converting kinetic energy into thermal energy?

options.option_text: A car accelerating on a flat road.
A block sliding down a rough inclined plane and heating up.
A ball rolling on a frictionless surface at a constant speed.
A pendulum swinging back and forth in a vacuum.

variants.question: Select all of the following that are effects of friction:

options.option_text: Conversion of kinetic energy to thermal energy.
Increase in the overall mechanical energy of a system.
Opposition to motion between two surfaces in contact.
Conversion of potential energy to kinetic energy.

variants.question: Which type of friction is the maximum frictional force before motion begins?

options.option_text: Sliding friction
Static friction
Fluid friction
Rolling friction

variants.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes static friction?

options.option_text: Static friction is the force that opposes the motion of two surfaces sliding against each other.
Static friction is the maximum frictional force that must be overcome before motion begins.
Static friction is the force that opposes the motion of an object rolling over a surface.
Static friction is a type of friction that occurs between a solid object and a fluid (liquid or gas).

variants.question: Select all the situations where static friction plays a crucial role:

options.option_text: A car moving at a constant speed on a highway.
A book resting on a table.
A box sliding down a ramp.
Walking without slipping.

variants.question: Which of the following is an example of drag?

options.option_text: A car moving on the road.
Air resistance on a parachute.
Friction between a box and a floor.
A book resting on a table.

variants.question: Which of the following scenarios demonstrate the effects of drag force? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: A feather falling slowly through the air.
A car rolling freely on a flat road with the engine off.
An airplane maintaining a constant speed and altitude.
A box sliding down a frictionless ramp.

variants.question: Which of the following best describes the effect of drag on an object moving through a fluid (like air or water)?

options.option_text: Drag assists the motion of the object.
Drag opposes the motion of the object.
Drag only affects objects in a vacuum.
Drag has no effect on the object's motion.

variants.question: According to Newton's Third Law, for every action force there is:

options.option_text: An equal force in the same direction.
An equal and opposite reaction force.
A smaller force in the same direction.
No reaction force.

variants.question: Which of the following statements correctly describes Newton's Third Law of Motion?

options.option_text: Forces always occur in pairs that are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.
A single force can exist without a corresponding reaction force.
Action and reaction forces act on the same object.
The reaction force is always greater than the action force.

variants.question: Which of the following are examples that illustrate Newton's Third Law? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: A book resting on a table exerts a force downward due to gravity, and the table exerts an equal and opposite force upward.
When you walk, your feet push backward on the Earth, and the Earth pushes forward on your feet, causing you to move forward.
A car accelerating forward experiences an equal and opposite force pushing it backward.
A rocket launching into space expels gases downward, and the gases exert an equal and opposite force upward on the rocket.

variants.question: What is characteristic of circular motion?

options.option_text: Constant speed and direction.
Constant speed and changing direction.
Constant direction and changing speed.
No change in speed or direction.

variants.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes an object undergoing uniform circular motion?

options.option_text: The object's velocity is constant.
The object's speed is constant, but its velocity changes.
The object's speed changes, but its velocity remains constant.
Both the object's speed and velocity change.

variants.question: An object is moving in a circle with a constant speed of 5 m/s. Which of the following are true about its motion? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: The object's kinetic energy is constant.
The object's velocity is constant.
The object is accelerating.
There is no net force acting on the object.

variants.question: Which force is responsible for maintaining an object's circular path?

options.option_text: Gravitational force
Centripetal force
Frictional force
Applied force

variants.question: An object is moving in a circle at a constant speed. Which of the following forces is directed towards the center of the circle?

options.option_text: Centrifugal force
Centripetal force
Frictional force
Gravitational force

variants.question: Which of the following statements are true regarding centripetal force? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: Centripetal force always points toward the center of the circular path.
Centripetal force is a fictitious force.
Centripetal force changes the speed of an object moving in a circle.
Centripetal force is responsible for maintaining circular motion.

variants.question: What happens to an object's motion if the centripetal force is suddenly removed?

options.option_text: It stops immediately.
It continues in circular motion.
It moves in a straight line tangent to its circular path.
It spirals inward.

variants.question: Which of the following statements correctly describes the motion of an object immediately after the centripetal force acting on it is removed?

options.option_text: The object will stop moving.
The object will continue moving in a circle with the same radius.
The object will move along a straight line tangent to the circle at the point where the force was removed.
The object will spiral inwards towards the center of the original circular path.

variants.question: An object is moving in a circle at a constant speed due to a centripetal force. Which of the following will happen if the centripetal force is suddenly doubled?

options.option_text: The object will move in a circle with a larger radius.
The object will move in a circle with a smaller radius.
The object will move in a straight line.
The object's speed will decrease.

variants.question: What is the moment of a force?

options.option_text: The push or pull acting on an object.
The turning effect produced by a force about a pivot.
The resistance to motion.
The measure of an object's inertia.

variants.question: Which of the following statements best describes the moment of a force?

options.option_text: It is the force multiplied by the time for which it acts.
It is the turning effect of a force around a fixed point.
It is the energy transferred when a force moves an object.
It is the rate of change of momentum.

variants.question: Select all the statements that correctly describe 'moment of force'.

options.option_text: It measures the turning effect of a force.
It is calculated as the product of force and the perpendicular distance from the pivot.
It is a vector quantity.
It is the same as the applied force.

variants.question: What is the standard unit of measurement for the moment of a force?

options.option_text: Newton (N)
Joule (J)
Newton metre (Nm)
Watt (W)

variants.question: Which of the following is the correct representation for the unit of moment of force?

options.option_text: N/m
Nm
N/m²
Nm²

variants.question: Select all the units that are NOT the standard unit of measurement for the moment of a force.

options.option_text: Newton (N)
Joule (J)
Newton metre (Nm)
Watt (W)

variants.question: According to the principle of moments, for an object to be in equilibrium:

options.option_text: The sum of clockwise moments must be greater than the sum of anticlockwise moments.
The sum of clockwise moments must be less than the sum of anticlockwise moments.
The sum of clockwise moments must equal the sum of anticlockwise moments.
The moments do not affect equilibrium.

variants.question: Which of the following statements correctly describe the principle of moments for an object in equilibrium? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: The total clockwise moment is equal to the total anticlockwise moment.
The sum of upward forces must equal the sum of downward forces.
The sum of clockwise moments must be greater than the sum of anticlockwise moments.
The object must not be rotating.

variants.question: A seesaw is balanced when a child sits on one end. If the child moves further away from the pivot, what happens to the anticlockwise moment they exert?

options.option_text: The anticlockwise moment increases.
The anticlockwise moment decreases.
The anticlockwise moment remains the same.
The clockwise moment increases.

variants.question: What conditions must be met for an object to be in equilibrium?

options.option_text: Net force must be zero
Net moment must be zero
Net force must be non-zero
Net moment must be non-zero

variants.question: Which of the following conditions must be met for an object to be in equilibrium? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: The net force acting on the object is zero.
The net moment acting on the object is zero.
The net force acting on the object is non-zero.
The net moment acting on the object is non-zero.

variants.question: An object is in translational equilibrium if:

options.option_text: The net force acting on the object is zero.
The net moment acting on the object is zero.
The object is rotating at a constant angular velocity.
The object has a constant linear velocity and zero angular velocity.

variants.question: What is the center of gravity?

options.option_text: The point where an object's entire mass is considered to act.
The point where an object's entire weight is considered to act.
The physical center of an object.
The point of balance of an object.

variants.question: Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the center of gravity of an object?

options.option_text: It is the point where the entire mass of the object is concentrated.
It is the point where the weight of the object appears to act.
It is always located at the geometric center of the object.
It is the point where the object experiences the greatest gravitational force.

variants.question: Select all the statements that correctly describe the center of gravity:

options.option_text: It is the point where the entire mass of an object is assumed to be concentrated.
It is the point about which the sum of the torques due to gravity is zero.
It is the point where the gravitational force appears to act.
For symmetrically shaped objects with uniform density, it is located at the geometric center.

variants.question: What is the general location of the center of gravity for symmetrical objects with uniform density?

options.option_text: At the geometric center.
At the edge of the object.
Outside the object.
Dependent on the orientation of the object.

variants.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the location of the center of gravity for symmetrical objects with uniform density?

options.option_text: It is always located at the geometric center of the object.
It is located at the point where the object's mass is most concentrated.
It is located outside the object.
It can be located anywhere within the object, depending on its shape.

variants.question: A cube of uniform density has sides of length 2 meters. Where is its center of gravity located?

options.option_text: At the center of one of its faces.
1 meter from each face.
2 meters from each face.
At one of its corners.

variants.question: When will an object topple?

options.option_text: When the vertical line through the center of gravity falls outside the base of support.
When the center of gravity is within the base of support.
When the object is perfectly balanced.
Toppling only occurs with external forces.

variants.question: Which of the following scenarios will cause an object to topple?

options.option_text: The vertical line through the center of gravity falls outside the base of support.
The object is pushed with a force directed towards its center of gravity.
The object's weight is evenly distributed across its base.
The object is placed on a perfectly level surface.

variants.question: Select all of the following conditions that increase an object's likelihood of toppling.

options.option_text: A higher center of gravity.
A wider base of support.
A vertical line through the center of gravity falling outside the base of support.
A lower center of gravity.

variants.question: Which of the following enhances stability?

options.option_text: Increasing the height of the center of gravity
Lowering the center of gravity
Reducing the base area
Using a lighter material

variants.question: A delivery truck has a high center of gravity. Which of the following actions would NOT improve the truck's stability?

options.option_text: Widening the wheelbase
Lowering the suspension
Loading heavy cargo on top
Increasing the weight of the chassis

variants.question: Which of the following factors contribute to the stability of an object? Select all that apply.

options.option_text: A low center of gravity
A narrow base of support
A wide base of support
A high center of gravity

variants.question: Match each force with its description.

options.optionB: Opposes motion between surfaces in contact

variants.question: Match the law/concept with its description.

options.optionB: Object at rest stays at rest unless acted upon by a net force
Acceleration is proportional to net force and inversely proportional to mass
Every action has an equal and opposite reaction
Spring extension is proportional to applied force
